chapters.title: Week 1: What Actually Is AI?
chapters.description: Demystify AI and understand what it really means for your charity work

lessons.title: AI Demystified - Understanding AI in Plain English

content.video_script: AI isn't robots taking over the world—it's actually much more mundane and much more useful than that. Think of AI as a very good pattern-spotter. If you show it enough examples of something, it gets brilliant at recognising similar things later. Three types you'll actually encounter: 1) Simple AI - Like spell-check or Netflix recommendations, 2) Smart AI - Like ChatGPT or voice assistants, 3) Fancy AI - Like medical diagnosis or climate modelling. For your charity? You'll mainly use type 2. Bottom line: AI is a powerful tool that can help you do your job better, faster, and sometimes more creatively.

lessons.title: AI Limitations and Risks - When AI Gets It Wrong

content.video_script: AI isn't perfect. In fact, it can be spectacularly wrong sometimes. Here's what you need to watch for: 1) Hallucinations - AI confidently making things up, 2) Bias - AI reflecting unfair assumptions from its training data, 3) Context blindness - Missing nuance that seems obvious to humans, 4) Data dependency - Only as good as what it's learned from. The good news? Awareness is 90% of the solution. Always verify, especially for important decisions. Think of AI as a brilliant but slightly unreliable intern—incredibly useful, but you'd never let them write to major donors unsupervised.

chapters.title: Week 3: Ethics and Responsible Use
chapters.description: Building an ethical framework for AI use in purpose-driven organisations

ethical_principles: Transparency: Your beneficiaries should know when they're interacting with AI
Fairness: AI shouldn't perpetuate discrimination—it should help break it down
Privacy: Beneficiary data deserves extra protection, not less
Human dignity: AI should enhance human relationships, not replace them
Mission alignment: AI should amplify your impact, not compromise your values
red_flags: AI making decisions about people's lives without human oversight
Using beneficiary data to train AI without proper consent
Automating away the human touch that defines your work
AI systems that you can't explain to stakeholders

ethical_dilemmas.dilemma: Your AI tool could help identify at-risk young people, but requires collecting sensitive personal data
An AI writing tool could help create grant applications faster, but might sound less authentic

lessons.title: Data Protection and Privacy
lessons.type: GDPR Compliance Guide + Privacy Impact Assessment

gdpr_key_points: Lawful basis for processing personal data with AI
Data minimisation - only use what you need
Purpose limitation - stick to original consent
Right to explanation for automated decisions
